chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A unifying reform would keep elections administered by states but reduce winner-take-all distortions so the presidency more reliably aligns with the national popular will. One workable path is a phased package: require proportional elector allocation (or a uniform ranked-choice tally for president) alongside an expanded House to rebalance representation, with a federal floor for ballot access, counting procedures, recount triggers, and post-election audits. That combination preserves federalism, makes more votes matter in more places, and strengthens legitimacy in close elections without forcing an abrupt, all-at-once rewrite.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should make the presidential outcome track the national popular will more closely while keeping states meaningfully involved, reducing winner-take-all distortions that concentrate power in a few swing states. A practical bridge is either adopting the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or requiring proportional allocation of each state’s electors, with ranked-choice/automatic runoff to ensure a majority-supported winner. Whatever path is chosen, pair it with clear, uniform baseline standards for ballot access, counting, recounts, and automatic audits so results are transparent, predictable, and broadly trusted.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: A practical reform should make presidential outcomes track the voters more closely while keeping states meaningfully involved, so no region feels ignored and close elections remain legitimate. A strong middle ground is ending winner-take-all by requiring proportional (or district-based) allocation of electors nationwide, and pairing it with clear, uniform standards for ballot access, counting, recounts, and risk-limiting audits. If broader agreement emerges, states could also pursue a carefully phased National Popular Vote approach with a ranked-choice or runoff backstop so the winner has majority support. The goal is a transparent system that rewards broad coalitions and gives voters in every state reason to participate.
